column4: for some stuff, you may need to actually log in as root as sudo will not work (usually crappily written proprietary software installers - i.e. matlab), in which case you just create a user named root and log in
but you probably won't need to do that if you're not installing anything special
there's a file /etc/fstab, you need to edit that so that there is a line in it for windows and a corresponding mount point
